qas.question: What did Shell initate after its 2005 purchase?

answers.text: its US$4.5 billion Arctic drilling program

qas.question: What executive initially led the Artic drilling project?
What caused the delay in drilling after Shell's 2008 purchase?

answers.text: the refurbishment of rigs, permit delays from the relevant authorities and lawsuits

qas.question: Shell's plans to drill in the Artic led to protests from which particular environmental group?
How much did the purchase of an offshore lease cost?
What Greenpeace executive protested the Arctic drilling?
When was Pete Slaiby taken off of the Arctic drilling program?
When was Pete Slaiby working in the North Sea?

context: Following the purchase of <a0_0>an offshore lease<a0_0/> in 2005, Shell initiated <a1_0>its <b5_0>US$4.5 billion<b5_0/> Arctic drilling program<a1_0/> in <b9_0>2006<b9_0/>, after the corporation purchased <b7_0>the "Kulluk"<b7_0/> oil rig and leased the Noble Discoverer drillship. At inception, the project was led by <a2_0><b6_0>Pete Slaiby<b6_0/><a2_0/>, a Shell executive who had previously worked in the North Sea. However, after the purchase of a second offshore lease in 2008, Shell only commenced drilling work in <b8_0>2012<b8_0/>, due to <a3_0>the refurbishment of rigs, permit delays from the relevant authorities and lawsuits<a3_0/>. The plans to drill in the Arctic led to protests from environmental groups, particularly <a4_0>Greenpeace<a4_0/>; furthermore, analysts in the energy field, as well as related industries, also expressed skepticism due to perceptions that drilling in the region is "too dangerous because of harsh conditions and remote locations".
